Fields.DialogueText: Nagato, what are you doing out on deck at this hour?
Good evening, Kanchou. I was keeping an eye on the ocean. I thought I felt the presence of a Funayūrei polluting these waters.
You know we have lookouts on watch who will sound the alarm if they spot any cause for it.
There's no such thing as too much caution, Kanchou. Plus, I have keen eyes - I'll be able to spot one of those filthy hulls before the lookouts.
I understand your intentions are noble, but you've given a few of the sailors on duty quite a shock over the last few nights, flitting in the dark like a ghost.
I see...
You know how superstitious sailors can be. They're still adjusting to being on board a ship with a Belle.
Forgive me, it was not my intention to scare anyone. I am still... adjusting to my new capabilities. And this Funayūrei...
This wouldn't be the first Morgana we've dealt with.
I have the utmost confidence in your abilities, Kanchou, but if you'll forgive me speaking my mind...
Of course - go ahead.
In naval wars, the victory usually goes to the side with the superior forces. We have little notion of our enemies' size, and yet we blunder ahead to attack.

Fields.MenuText: It is worrying, but we don't have any choice but to fight.
We'll learn more about them as we fight. With each victory, we grow better at dealing with the Morganas.
We don't exactly have the option of negotiating a ceasefire, Nagato. We have no choice but to "blunder ahead."

Fields.DialogueText: I know. I just wish I knew the odds. It's difficult to strategize against an unknown opponent.
You're right, Kanchou. We'll just have to be quick learners.
Forgive me, I did not mean to cause offense. I know this position is one we were forced into.
In any event, I suppose staring at the sea won't reveal much about the Funayūrei.
You're right. You should trust the crew to do their jobs.
Ah! Kanchou! Look there! To port! Funayūrei...
Are you ready for a fight?
I have to be.
@BATTLE
Kanchou, I was wondering if I could make a request of you.
As long as it's reasonable, of course, and yours generally are. What is it?
I was hoping you could requisition some matcha green tea the next time we are in port. I've used up the last of mine, and I miss the taste of home.
Isn't that a bit... frivolous, Nagato?
No, of course not. It is one of my most important jobs to represent and uphold the culture of Japan. It's a duty I take very seriously.
That's a very serious smile.
If you do this for me, I'll give you something special.
Hmm. What's this 'something special'?
Match your wits against mine and guess.

Fields.MenuText: A book on strategy, perhaps?
A kiss?
I don't have time for guessing games.

Fields.DialogueText: You know me well, Kanchou... but not enough to know those books are my most prized possessions. I wouldn't give them up, even for matcha.
Kanchou! This is a serious matter.
No time for testing your wits? Perhaps they're too dull, then.
Here's what I'll give you! One fresh natsumikan, from the city of Nagato.
A fruit? How do you have a fresh fruit?
A lady has her ways, and she doesn't talk about them. Do we have a deal? It's a useful fruit. It will prevent you from getting scurvy.
Ha, I suppose we do. I'll ask the quartermaster to look for your tea the next time we make port.
Excellent. I say we seal the deal by putting both our wits into outwitting the Funayūrei lurking on the horizon.
@BATTLE
The dinner yesterday was excellent! Give my compliments to your chef - he truly understands the intricacies of Japanese cuisine.
I'll pass it along. I'm sure he'll be ecstatic at the praise.
It made me miss my homeland... Do you ever miss home, Kanchou?

Fields.MenuText: I do, but I know I'm fighting to protect it. I hope to return there when this war is over.
I try not to think of it, Nagato.
I would rather be out at sea than stuck on land, no matter the port.

Fields.DialogueText: I hope so too, Kanchou. I will do my utmost to assure you can return!
Ah... I understand. I'm sorry to bring it up, Kanchou.
I'm flattered that you enjoy my company so, Kanchou!
Do you not consider the ship to be a type of home, for you?
No, Kanchou. This ship is me. I'm... an extension of it. But home is in Japan. Home is in my birthplace of Kure, with my sister Mutsu, but home is also in the province of Nagato.
Belles can be strange, sometimes.
Home is an intricate word for us Belles. But I suppose humans can belong to many places at once as well...
Kanchou! The Funayūrei are approaching!
Now there's a beast without a homeland.
@BATTLE
We drove them back to whatever hole they call home! Ha!
I've never seen you so... enthusiastic, Nagato.
Ah, forgive me, Kanchou. I merely... let my passions get the best of me.
Kanchou, I...
*ALARM*
Hold that thought, Nagato.
@BATTLE
Nagato? Is something wrong?
Oh... no. Nothing is wrong.
That battle felt... strange. I didn't feel your influence on the ship like I usually do.
It felt like commanding a ship without a Belle.
... Forgive me, Kanchou. I was... distracted.
By what? What's wrong? You look like you're about to faint!

Fields.MenuText: You're my Belle. If something is wrong, I need to know so I can help you.
I am your captain, Nagato. I order you to tell me what is wrong.
Your distraction directly impacts the safety of every man and woman on this ship.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm... I'm sorry Kanchou, it's just hard to speak of, and I'm ashamed of letting myself be distracted.
...Yes, Kanchou, but you don't need to be so rude about it.
I know. I shouldn't have let it happen. It was shameful of me to be distracted, but someone I love was in distress.
What happened?
I share a connection with my sister ship, Mutsu, though she has not awoken. We were forged and constructed out of the same metal and wood, side by side in Kure.
You Belles certainly make life strange. But I can see how that would be useful.
I could feel her engaged in a great fight with one of the Funayūrei...
Mutsu's crew put up a noble fight, but they were no match... and she was badly damaged.
What happened? Did she sink?
No... she managed to limp away. Her kanchou was clever, and wise, just like you. But... I can see that Funayūrei's ship in my head.
I think it might be best if you get some rest.
Nagato, I've been looking everywhere for you. What are you doing in my quarters?
Forgive me, Kanchou. I'm sorry. I... had a disagreement with a few of your officers.
They told me. I've had half the ship looking for you. I didn't expect to find you here.
I'm sorry, Senshou. I just wanted to be alone.
They shouldn't have tried to remove your chrysanthemum crest.
It's my kikusui. It marks me for who I am, the lead ship of my line. Before the formation of this Protection Force, I was the flagship of the Japanese fleet.
I know.
I don't mean to boast. I merely mean it is part of my identity. I don't want it stripped from me.
I serve the common good gladly, but I am a Japanese ship. I feel some of your sailors are ill at ease with that fact.

Fields.MenuText: You're right, but some cannot put aside the ongoing conflict for the greater good as easily as you can.
It's difficult to mold a fighting force out of sailors from countries at war.
It's understandable that some find it hard to put aside the ongoing conflict. You shouldn't have been so harsh on those men.

Fields.DialogueText: I suppose you're right. I just wish I could proudly be who I am without offending the crew.
They were trying to tear a piece of me off, Kanchou. I don't think you would respond kindly if someone tried to take your rank... or one of your limbs.
That argument is weak. They merely wanted an excuse to remove the reminder of my allegiance.
Don't worry, I won't allow you to be stripped of anything. Regardless, this encounter proves that the Protection Force isn't entirely unified against the Morganas.
Speaking of Funayūrei, Kanchou, I hear the alarms. Their ships are on the horizon!
We'll have to worry about this later, then. I hope you and those officers can put aside your differences.
@BATTLE
Avance... Navigue...
What are you reading, Nagato?
It's a history of Napoleon's naval career... I borrowed it from one of your French seamen.
I didn't know you were a fan of Napoleon.
I don't particularly care for the man himself, but there is a lot to be learned from the failures of great people.
Such as?
Well, the importance of naval superiority, for one. If Napoleon's navy had been as disciplined as the British navy, he might have fared better.
Are you thinking about the Morganas again?
I'm hoping they have the same failings as Napoleon, Kanchou. I just wish I could read French better. It's giving me a headache trying to get through this.
Well, I'll be able to give you a break from that, at least. There's a Funayūrei closing in.
@BATTLE
I overheard a few of the officers talking about Injustice being sighted close by. Is it true?
Yes, it is. The fleet does its best to track the movements of Morganas, and according to radio chatter Injustice may be moving in our direction.
Are you going to be all right if it comes to a fight? This was the ship who attacked your sister, after all.
... I have to be. I will merely have to prepare.
Are you sure?
The more disturbing thing is, despite our ability to communicate quickly between ships, we still have such trouble tracking the movements of the Funayūrei.
You're evading my question.
I'm not. I'm pondering a question that is far more important to the war as a whole.
But let us put both out of our minds for now, and deal with the Morganas.
@BATTLE
Kanchou! I believe it is time to sound the alarm!
Are you sensing...
Yes, Kanchou. Now!
@BATTLE
Kanchou, I think your coat is looking a little threadbare... and battle worn! That last encounter ripped it up.
I know, but I haven't had time to get it replaced, and I probably won't for a while.
I could fix it up, if you would like.
You can sew?
Not much, but I am a fair hand at sashiko. It's similar to embroidery, but it will strengthen the seams of your coat until you have time to get a new one.

Fields.MenuText: That sounds useful. Thank you, Nagato.
Are you trying to mother me, Nagato?
So long as you don't start sewing chrysanthemum crests onto it.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm so glad! It will give me something to do, rather than fretting about the condition of my guns and the location of Funayūrei all day.
No, of course not. I know you can take care of yourself, but you don't have the same skills as I do.
I'm perfectly capable of keeping my allegiance to you and my allegiance to my Emperor separate, Kanchou.
Excellent! I'll get started right away.
*ALARM*
There's a Funayūrei trying to slip by to starboard! She's got a quick craft and her fleet is not far behind. One of my lieutenants estimates she's going at twenty-one knots.
I-I believe we should be able to catch her, Kanchou. I'm far faster. But that flag she's flying... that's Injustice.
Nagato, I need you to have your wits about you in this fight.
I'm fine, Kanchou! Worry about the Funayūrei, not me.
@BATTLE
What was that, Nagato?
Our gunnery crews reported your guns firing wildly, out of their control.
You're supposed to be working with our crew, not against it! Do you doubt the capabilities of me and my crew?
N-No, Kanchou, of course not... I just got... caught up in it all.
We're all lucky we managed to beat those Morganas off, but we have thirty casualties on our hands.
I'm sorry, Kanchou. I... I just wanted to hurt her.

Fields.MenuText: I understand you want revenge, but you have to control yourself.
What happened to all your caution and coordination? You always lecture me on it.
Those injuries and deaths might have been avoided if you had not been caught up in your vendetta.

Fields.DialogueText: I will, Kanchou. I will never make this sort of mistake again, I promise.
I... I don't know, Kanchou...
We'll speak more of this later.
Kanchou, may I speak with you?
What is it, Nagato? I have to finish my reports.
Well, I... Kanchou! You're bleeding!
Hmm? Oh. I didn't notice. It's just a scratch.
You should have gone to see one of the ship's doctors.
The medical staff has many more urgent things to worry about than a few scrapes.
I'll fix you up, then. I have a medical kit, and I've picked up a bit of knowledge in my years of service.

Fields.MenuText: Very well, I'll trust myself to your hands.
Have you always had that, or did you just will it into existence?
I'm not sure I trust your medical knowledge...

Fields.DialogueText: I'm so glad you still trust me, Kanchou.
Of course I've always had it. It's just another part of my identity.
Nonsense. I've learned from the best surgeons the Imperial Fleet has to offer.
(some time later) There you go, all patched up. You should be healed in a few days' time.
Damn, there's the alarm. Looks like we can't have peace and quiet yet... I hope you'll be able to work with the crew this time, Nagato.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Flitting about while keeping watch again, I see.
I'm not flitting about! I'm quite substantial, as you can see. I don't want to scare any of our seamen again.
So you have learned.
I've always known sailors are superstitious. I just didn't anticipate them turning those superstitions on their own Belle.
You can be a bit aloof, Nagato. Don't you get lonely, keeping to yourself?
Hmm. That isn't what you want to talk to me about, Kanchou.
You're right.
... I'm really sorry, Kanchou. I shouldn't have tried to take control of the fight myself. I just got scared.

Fields.MenuText: Scared? You seemed more angry than scared.
I understand, but we all need to be able to keep our heads cool in a fight.
That's not something I ever thought I would hear you admit.

Fields.DialogueText: I was just trying to compensate for my lack of courage, Kanchou. I suppose I overcompensated.
I know. In the future, I will, I promise. I will not make the same mistake twice.
... It's a hard thing to admit.
I'm supposed to be the best ship Japan has to offer. I'm supposed to be an excellent representative of my country in the fight against the Funayūrei.
I'm supposed to know what I am doing. But honestly, Kanchou... before I chose you as my commander, I had seen barely any combat at all.
I see.
I felt what happened to Mutsu, and I got scared... And I wanted to beat the Funayūrei who hurt her, but I was afraid that it was beyond me.
I can barely apply any of the naval strategy I have learned to this fight, and my crew doesn't seem to trust or like me very much, and... I'm just not a very good Belle, Kanchou.
None of us had any experience fighting Morganas until recently. All of us are still learning. All of us are still scared sometimes.
Regardless of how you see yourself, you are an intelligent, quick-witted Belle, but you do need to work with your captain and crew, not against us.
...You're speaking sense, Kanchou. I'm sorry for losing my temper, and I'm sorry for being... aloof.
But I think I will quickly have a chance to redeem myself.
@BATTLE
You look tired, Kanchou. Has that representative from the League of Nations been wearing you down?
You have a keen eye, Nagato. I just managed to pass him off to my first mate. He's been chattering in my ear ceaselessly since coming aboard.
His only job is to inspect my ship and crew, and sit tight until we pass him off to the next ship, but the man thinks he is a grand tactician.
It is most irritating when people try to overstep their ranks. Are those maps?
Ah, they were a gift from the representative. His hobby is marking the locations of each known battle between a Morgana and one of our ships...
If you have no use for it, I would love to take it!

Fields.MenuText: Of course. It's good to see you so enthusiastic, Nagato.
Take it off my hands, I have no use for it.
What would you want with some hobbyist's map?

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you, Kanchou! I'll put it to good use.
I'll put it to good use, Kanchou. It's best not to waste anything in war times.
I have a use in mind for it, and maps are always interesting.
The Atlantic... the Pacific... It's disturbing just how many battles we've fought, and yet the Funayūrei seem barely bloodied.
They're unlike any enemy any navy of this world has ever encountered, but we're learning how to beat them.
The lack of a homeland should be a hinderance to them, but instead it seems a blessing. We have no place to blockade, or to send armies or even spies...
Ah, Kanchou, there's Funayūrei taunting us on the horizon. They are hungry to claim me, but they will learn the hard way.
@BATTLE
Some of your English seamen were using some incredibly degrading words in reference to me today, Kanchou.
Unfortunately, seamen can be coarse. Do you want me to have a word with them?
No thank you, Kanchou. I spoke with them myself. I think I gave them a bit of a shock, but they agreed to be more respectful in the future.
You look quite pleased with yourself.
I even made them blush! They were quite ashamed. It was actually rather endearing.
Ha, I'm impressed.
I shared some of my matcha with them, and I think that took the edge off my lecture.
I'm glad you're happy with the restock. Did the quartermaster get the right kind?
Yes, Kanchou, it's excellent tea. I only wish I had the time and tools to do a proper tea ceremony.
Tea time will have to wait for now, I'm afraid. I believe there are Morganas.
@BATTLE
Augh! My tea is cold now.
Yet another crime committed by our enemies... forcing Nagato to drink cold tea.
It really is a cruel thing to do.
I'm glad to be rid of the League of Nations representative.
Your days will certainly be quieter. I could barely get a word in when he was around. Silence is an art, and a respectable guest should know when to use it.
I've never met such a self-important man. He could have been royalty, the way he strutted around.
Hah! That man could never pass for royalty. I've had two crown princes walk my boards, and they were far different from him.
Really? You haven't mentioned that before.
Well... bragging is not respectable. But soon into my naval career, Tennō, then the Crown Prince of Japan, inspected me.
And when Prince Edward visited Japan shortly after, a dinner party was hosted in his honor right here.
Hmm. To think I eat dinner at the same table as a prince. You should tell that story next time we dine with my officers.
Oh, like I said, I wouldn't want to brag.
It's an interesting story. Most people would love to hear a bit of gossip about those in high places. It would give them something to talk about.
I hadn't thought of it like that, Kanchou. But you shouldn't put your mind to dinner just yet. I can feel the slippery presence of Funayūrei creeping closer to us.
@BATTLE
It's amazing the diversity of the crew we have onboard, Kanchou.
Does it bother you?
It was strange at first, but not unwelcome. I'll gladly welcome any hands you recruit. I trust your judgment. But I will admit it made me more hesitant to interact with them...
I noticed.
But I've been speaking more with the enlisted seamen, and it's actually rather fascinating, hearing their stories. Especially those about their homes.
You've been far and wide, around more of the world than many of them, most likely.
That's true, but I still slept then. And I haven't had much of an opportunity to interact with other cultures these last few years... I forgot how interesting people could be.
I'm glad you're getting on better with the crew. Just make sure you don't distract anyone from their duties.
Of course, Kanchou. I am the epitome of discretion and timing. And speaking of time, I believe we have Funayūrei to deal with. How punctual.
@BATTLE
Captain, enemy vessel spotted due north.
Very good. Sound the alarm!
@BATTLE
I see someone has helped herself to the sake we picked up in port.
Kanchou, I'm not solely capable of enjoying things that are Japanese! I'll have you know I'm drunk on the fine Italian wine your chef likes to serve...
Ha, fair enough. Any occasion? Or just beating another Morgana?
Hmm. Do I need any occasion to enjoy myself, Kanchou? Why don't you join me? There's still more than enough wine left from dinner...

Fields.MenuText: Why not? I haven't had the opportunity to relax in a while.
Fine, but just a bit. We have to remain cautious, as you're fond of reminding me.
Not now. We're in Morgana-infested waters and I have to keep my wits about me.

Fields.DialogueText: Good! Relaxing now and then is good for your health.
Cautious... haha... I suppose I do say that.
You're no fun tonight, Kanchou.
I was wondering... if... if Mahan says world power goes to those with control of the ocean... then... then could Belles rule the world?
I think you need to stop drinking and reading naval history at the same time, Nagato.
It's better than drinking and... and thinking.
Thinking of what?
Of the depths of the ocean... even when I slept, I feared drowning. I don't know if I could drown. I love the ocean, but it is vast, and cold, and merciless...
I think you've had enough, Nagato.
*ALARM*
I can feel you close by, Funayūrei. I cannot see you. Show yourself!
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Out here again with my telescope, I see. Can't you leave lookout duty to the sailors?
It's not your telescope, Kanchou. I borrowed it from one of the women who were on duty last watch.
My point still stands.
I used to sit out here because I could sense the Funayūrei, and I wanted to be prepared. I was afraid if I rushed blindly into the fight, then I wouldn't be able to remain composed.

Fields.MenuText: You had a point there.
I suppose you were right, considering the incident with Injustice.
Even with time to prepare, you still lost control.

Fields.DialogueText: I did, but I still managed to commit an error...
I fully anticipated that fight, and yet I still bungled it.
... You're right. I will strive to do better next time.
Even discounting that... the Funayūrei spread these feelings of... discontent, of wrongness. In all the years and years I sailed before I woke, I never felt anything like it.
When I catch them slipping in at the edges of my awareness... it's similar to the feeling that someone is staring at you.
So you come out here to watch.
Kanchou, I was thinking, maybe you could put me into the watch schedule? If you give me a few watch shifts a day, it would normalize this eccentricity of mine.
I don't see why I couldn't, but are you sure you want to commit yourself to the drudgery?
Of course, Kanchou. I'm not above it, if that's what you mean.
I was just making sure. You do have an air of... sophistication about you, usually.
I may be a lady, but first and foremost I am the soul of this ship. No work onboard it is improper for me.
Kanchou! Injustice is bearing down on us!
She probably thinks she can finish us off this time.
Let's show her the danger of overconfidence.
@BATTLE
Hahahaha! We won!
It's a pyrrhic victory, with the state you are in. Nagato, you're...
Taking water, I know. But we won! It's not so bad. *wince*
If we don't move quickly, you could sink and take all of us with you.
As soon as you think I am unfixable, evacuate all hands to the lifeboats and let me sink. Don't throw away their lives for me.

Fields.MenuText: I couldn't abandon you!
I don't want to abandon you, but I'll do what is right for our crew.
In that situation, abandoning ship would be the only logical choice.

Fields.DialogueText: It's your duty, Kanchou. Do what is best for your crew, and for the war.
Good. I'm glad I chose you as my kanchou.
You're right. We can't let ourselves get caught up in emotion in a time like this.
Go. Coordinate the repair efforts. If it fails... it's been an honor, Kanchou.
Kanchou! You fixed me!
Nagato! Where have you been?
I'm sorry. It was hard to... remain present, when I was so badly damaged.
I was worried I had lost you for good.
I admit to being equally afraid of that possibility. It seemed easy to sound brave but... to be honest, I was terrified. The thought of being stuck down in the cold, and the dark...
I wouldn't let the ocean swallow you.
*ALARM*
I know. I knew I made a good choice when I chose you.
@BATTLE
I won! I won, I won, I wooon...
What are you yelling about? I've never seen you so happy before...
A few of your officers have been teaching me how to play poker...
So that's why you've been spending so much time in the wardroom. What do you even have to gamble?
I have a bit of money. Well, I had a bit of money. Now I have obtained substantially more... poker may not be as much fun as Go or chess, but it's certainly more profitable.

Fields.MenuText: Hah, I would have liked to see their faces when you outplayed them.
It's good that you and my officers are becoming so comfortable with each other.
You shouldn't try to take my officers' wages for fun, Nagato. You don't need the money.

Fields.DialogueText: They were amazed! I don't think they expected me to take to it so well.
They have been very welcoming. I didn't realize I would enjoy myself this much.
Oh, don't worry. I'll lose a few hands next game so they'll continue letting me play.
Maybe I will enlist one of the officers to pick me up a new book the next time we make port...
If you have your heart set on a book, I could probably buy it for you. What do you want?
Another book by Alfred Thayer Mahan, or any naval strategist. But first, there's a Funayūrei approaching who is in need of the same lesson your officers learned.
@BATTLE
How are you feeling, Nagato?
Kanchou? How do you mean?
The engineers are afraid our last few battles might have shaken something loose again.
The ship is perfectly operational, Kanchou. To the best of my knowledge.
Are you sure about that?
Now you're the one being paranoid, Kanchou. I'm flattered that you care for me so, but I promise, the Nagato is in top condition.
Ha, very well. You can't blame me for being concerned after all we've been through.
But I'm glad. We've been tasked with chasing down a Morgana that was harrying a few non-Belle Protection Force ships this morning.
We have every probability of catching her. When I was younger, my kanchou liked to brag that I could reach a clip of twenty-six knots an hour.

Fields.MenuText: That may be true, but it was some time ago.
I've never seen you reach that speed.
You're not the youngest ship.

Fields.DialogueText: It's true I've been retrofitted since then, but I'm still swift.
Well, I may not be designed for that speed anymore... but you know very well I'm a swift ship.
Kanchou! It's rude to comment on age like that!
I don't believe there is a Funayūrei in this ocean who could outpace me on a good day.
Overconfidence, Nagato.
It's not overconfidence, it's a simple assessment of my strengths.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
What was that ruckus?
Two of your petty officers got into a scuffle, Kanchou. Don't worry. I got the situation under control.
You did? What was it about?
Well, it was between Mr. Arthur, one of the Englishman, and Ms. Antonelli, one of the Italians.
Their disagreement was centered on the current state of the war in England, and the land war in general.
Ah. How did you resolve it? And... why?
Well... I was thinking, as the Belle of this ship, it is my responsibility just as much as it is yours to make sure things run smoothly. And they can't if the crew is embroiled in fights.
A lack of unification could destroy us.
That's true. Unfortunately a level of tension is to be expected onboard a ship crewed by sailors from opposing sides of a war. How did you resolve the fight?
I reminded the officers - after a few men helped me pull them apart - that the war we are fighting is much greater and more potentially destructive than any war between humans.
War is horrible, but the Funayūrei are unique in that we cannot communicate with them and we have little idea of what they want.
That's true of plenty of human armies.
But human wars are usually governed, or at least restrained, by words and diplomacy.
The naval treaties made after the Great War are the only reason the navies of the world did not spin into an arms race and hurry to outdo each other in matters of destruction.
But the Funayūrei have no such limits. Perhaps destruction is their only goal. We have no way of knowing, but we're fighting to protect all of our countries.
Hmm. That's an impressive speech. Did it work?
They already knew most of it, they just needed a reminder. They looked rather ashamed of themselves. And I... may of invoked your name as well.
Oh?
I said their first loyalty should be to you, just like mine is. You fight the Funayūreis tirelessly. They should not seek to undo your efforts.

Fields.MenuText: I'm flattered that you think of me so highly, Nagato.
It's disappointing they had to be reminded of these sorts of things in the first place.
I'm glad you stopped the fight, but of course they will have to be appropriately disciplined.

Fields.DialogueText: My respect for you increases every day, Kanchou.
It is, but unfortunately unsurprising. It's not easy for anyone to set aside loyalties to their country, even for the greater good.
Of course, Kanchou. I merely sought to get at the root of the conflict.
Is your first loyalty really to me?
Ah... don't look so proud, Kanchou. You are my kanchou, and I am, first and foremost, your Belle. Just like the crew should be, first and foremost, your crew.
Hmm. We have our orders to engage with Morganas lurking off the coast. That ought to bring the crew together.
@BATTLE
I have two presents for you, Nagato.
Really? It isn't even my birthday, Kanchou.
Well, I'm not sure one of them will be pleasing to you...
Don't leave me in suspense, Kanchou.
Injustice has been prowling around in these waters and picking off ships carrying supplies to Protection Force aircraft carriers and destroyers.
And we have been tasked with chasing her off?
Exactly.
Good. I have been waiting for a chance to repay her for what she did to me last time.
I'm glad you're so eager. I hope the crew is as well.
We should run them through drills today, before setting off. We know very well the class and armaments Injustice has. We have time to prepare a strategy.

Fields.MenuText: I'm glad you're taking this so calmly.
She almost sank us last time. I think a bit of caution would be warranted.
You're behaving a little flippantly for my tastes.

Fields.DialogueText: We have faced her before, and we know her strengths and weaknesses. With those advantages, there is no reason why I shouldn't be calm.
We beat her last time. This time, we know enough to beat her more effectively.
Forgive me, Kanchou, I don't mean to seem flippant, but in this fight we at least will have a strategy. That is all I need.
This time, we will be the hunter, not the hunted.
That's true.
You mentioned you have another present for me? Wait, no, it can wait. Perhaps the Funayūrei caught wind of our assignment. There are closing in on us.
@BATTLE
Give me the spyglass... Injustice looks a bit different than before?
... These Funayūrei are strange entities, Kanchou.

Fields.MenuText: Our strategy will work, if we coordinate. Be confident, Nagato.
Keep your wits about you, and we will win this.
Be cautious, and remember to work with the crew, and not against them.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course. I am, Kanchou.
I will.
I learned my lesson that first fight, Kanchou.
I'm ready to beat them.
@BATTLE
Nagato! Watch her run!
We should chase her down, Kanchou. We could destroy her for good if we give chase.
No.
What?
Our orders are to guard these waters, and defend the supply ships. She won't be bothering them anymore.
But...
Overextending ourselves for vengeance wouldn't be logical.
... You're right, Kanchou.
Kanchou? I was wondering... you never told me what the other present you had for me was, which was completely understandable, given the excitement, but... I'm curious.
Oh! Of course, it slipped my mind. Last time I was in port, I found this.
Ah! A Japanese tea set!
I remembered you lamenting not having the right tea set for your matcha.
Ah, thank you Kanchou! I could do a proper tea ceremony now! I'd love to do one with you, if we ever have a bit of quiet.
We rarely seem to, but I'm willing to pledge the next quiet day to you.
Oh, Kanchou, thank you! It means so much to me that you remembered my frivolous hobbies.
I don't think they're frivolous if they're important to you.
Thank you, Kanchou.

Fields.MenuText: I'm glad to have you at my side, Nagato.
You know, you don't have to call me Kanchou. You're welcome to call me by my first name.
